awd_titl_txt: Transition Metal Complexes with Multiple Ligand Bonds as the Lewis Base Component of Frustrated Lewis Pairs
awd_abstract_narration:
The design and discovery of new catalysts, and new catalytic transformations, is critical for the efficient utilization of our natural resources.  With this award from the Chemical Catalysis Program of the NSF Division of Chemistry, Professor Ison is developing catalysts that contain a bond between an oxygen atom and a transition metal, specifically rhenium.  The rhenium-oxygen bond has unique reactivity that is being used to develop fundamentally new catalytic reactions.  For example, new ways to convert carbon dioxide into useful chemicals are being investigated.  Dr. Ison is involved in a variety of outreach efforts aimed at recruiting high school and undergraduate students to pursue careers in STEM fields.  In addition, Dr. Ison is engaged in the training of high school teachers to incorporate aspects of his research into the high school science curriculum.

This award from the Chemical Catalysis Program of the Chemistry Division supports research by Dr. Elon Ison who is designing new catalysts that contain a rhenium-ligand multiple bond. In this approach, five-coordinate square pyramidal complexes with a terminal multiple bond to a heteroatom in the apical position are utilized so that the electronic consequences of this geometric arrangement can be used to develop catalysts for the activation of small molecules. Dr. Ison is developing a new type of frustrated Lewis pair (FLP) catalyst, where a transition metal oxo acts as the Lewis base component. These new FLPs are effective as catalysts for hydrogenation, and involve a new mechanism for substrate activation by a transition metal complex where the metal does not directly participate, but instead plays an ancillary role. Fundamental mechanistic studies as well as high-level density functional theory(DFT) calculations are being used to understand the structure and reactivity of these FLPs and to design new catalytic systems In this project, Dr. Ison is developing FLP catalyst for asymmetric hydrogenations and the activation of carbon dioxide. Dr. Ison is involved in a variety of outreach efforts aimed at recruiting high school and undergraduate students to pursue careers in STEM fields. In addition, Dr. Ison is engaged in the training of high school teachers to incorporate aspects of his research into the high school science curriculum.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit.

Tuning the reactivity of Re≡O/boronFLPs.

Steric and electronic effects in the hydrogenation of unactivated olefins. We have explored the steric and electronic demands of olefin hydrogenation with oxorhenium/Lewis acid FLPs. By performing systematic manipulations to the sterics and electronics of the diamidoamine ligand, the Lewis acid component of the FLP, and the X-type ligand on rhenium, the catalytic activity of this new class of FLPs was increased from TONs of 20 in our initial publication to 840 for the catalytic hydrogenation of tert-butyl ethylene. To date, in catalysis, the most significant application of FLPs involves the catalytic hydrogenation of unsaturated substrates. For the hydrogenation of olefins, the presence of electronegative atoms (O, N) on the substrate is desirable in most cases as these atoms enable Lewis acid coordination and the stabilization (via lone pair donation) of carbocations that arise during the course of the catalytic reaction (vide infra). In contrast, catalytic hydrogenations of unfunctionalized (no heteroatoms) olefins are much more difficult. By rationally designing oxorhenium complexes as the Lewis base component of an FLP we were able to achieve 840 TON for the hydrogenation of tert-butyl ethylene. At the time, this was unprecedented reactivity for catalytic hydrogenation of an unfunctionalized olefin with an FLP. 

Frustrated Lewis Pairs (FLPs) in CatalyticHydrosilylation Reactions. We described a series of cationic Re(III)complexes [(DAAm)Re(CO)(NCCH3)2][X][DAAm = N,N-bis(2-arylaminoethyl)methylamine; aryl = C6F5, Mes,[X = OTf, BArF4 [BArF4 = tetrakis[3,5-(trifluoromethyl)phenyl]borate)], BF4, PF6], andthe analogue [(DAmA)Re(CO)(Cl)2] [DAmA =N,N-bis(2-arylamineethyl)methylamino; aryl =C6F5] that efficiently catalyze the hydrosilylationof aldehydes.15 In the mechanism for this reaction,(Figure 4), a cationic rhenium species wasproposed to activate R3SiH followed bynucleophilic attack of the aldehyde substrate, i.e.analogous to Piers’ mechanism with B(C6F5)3. Ina follow up publication we presented a unifiedmechanism for Re catalyzed hydrosilylationreactions based on the Piers FLP-type mechanismfor B(C6F5)3 that allows for the functionalizationof weak nucleophiles.16 An energy decompositionanalysis (EDA) study suggest that the frustratedLewis pair reactivity arises from a change in theratio of orbital and steric energy contributions tothe interaction energy between the Lewis acid andbase. This allows frustrated Lewis pairs andadducts to be described by a spectrum ofreactivity. Understanding the nature of covalentand non-covalent interactions within thisspectrum has important implications for therational design of new catalysts. Controlling the Lewis acidity of the metal component is critical for the selectivity of catalytic hydrosilylation. This strategy has allowed for the reduction of ketones and nitriles which were unreactive under previously reported conditions. The FLP reactivity described is quite general for rhenium complexes and the mechanisms proposed lay the foundation for the design of new catalytic systems.

Broader Impacts

Training and Development.

Four graduate students, Nikola Lambic (ExxonMobil) and Damaris Perez(Catalent Pharma Solutions), (2018), Caleb Brown (Virginia Military Institute) and Alexis Guzmán (Catalent Pharma Solutions) have received PhDs as a result of this award.

Undergraduates, Nikki Wolford (University of Rochester, REU2016), Karam Idrees (Northwestern University, REU 2017) and Kyra Brakefield (University of Oregon,REU 2018) are all currently pursuing PhDs in chemistry.Conference Papers and Presentations.

This award has resulted in 12 invited lectures and presentations and 8 posters or presentations at national conferences or symposia.

Publications. This award has resulted in 8 peer reviewed publications and 2 book chapters.


Last Modified: 09/04/2021
Modified by: Elon A Ison
